From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

localiser (plural localisers)

  1. Alternative form of localizer.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • rocailles

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From local +‎ -iser.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /lɔ.ka.li.ze/
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

localiser

  1. (transitive) to locate; to run to ground, to run to earth
    Est-ce que tu as réussi à les localiser sur ton GPS ?
    Have you managed to locate them on your GPS?
  2. (transitive) to localise

compound — simple imperative of avoir + past participle — simple imperative of avoir + past participle simple imperative of avoir + past participle —
1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]
  • localisation

Further reading

[edit]
  • “localiser”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • collerais, oscillera

Norman

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

local +‎ -iser

Verb

[edit]

localiser

  1. (Jersey, computing, etc.) to localize

Derived terms

[edit]
  • localisâtion (“localization”)
